section.title: Compiling multiple WSDLs that share a common schema
section.para: Occasionally, a server will expose multiple services that share common schema types. Perhaps the "common schema types" are from an industry-standard schema, or perhaps the server was developed by a Java-first web service toolkit and the services all use the same Java classes as parameter/return values. When compiling such a WSDL, it's desirable for the shared portion to produce the same Java classes to avoid duplicates. There are two ways to do this.
The easy way is for you to compile all the WSDLs into the same package:
section.programlisting: $ wsimport -p org.acme.foo first.wsdl $ wsimport -p org.acme.foo second.wsdl
section.para: The Java classes that correspond to the common part will be overwritten multiple times, but since they are identical, in the end this will produce the desired result. If the common part is separated into its own namespace, you can use a JAXB customization so that the common part will go to the overwritten package while everything else will get its own package.
section.programlisting: $ cat common.jaxb <bindings xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/jaxb" version="2.1"> <bindings scd="x-schema::tns" xmlns:tns="http://common.schema.ns/"> <schemaBindings> <package name="org.acme.foo.common" /> </schemaBindings> </bindings> </bindings> $ wsimport -p org.acme.foo.first first.wsdl -b common.jaxb $ wsimport -p org.acme.foo.second second.wsdl -b common.jaxb
section.para: You can also compile the schema upfront by xjc, then use its episode file when later invoking wsimport. For this to work, the common schema needs to have a URL that you can pass into xjc. If the schema is inlined inside the WSDL, you'll have to pull it out into a separate file.
section.programlisting: $ xjc -episode common.episode common.xsd $ wsimport wsdl-that-uses-common-schema.wsdl -b common.episode
section.para: This will cause wsimport to refer to classes that are generated from XJC earlier.
For more discussion on this, please see this forum thread.

section.title: How to get simple and better typed binding
section.para: wsimport uses JAXB RI's XJC tool internally to achive XML Schema to Java binding. The default behaviour is strictly as per JAXB 2.x specification. However it does not work for everyone, for example if you want to map xs:anyURI to java.net.URI instead of java.lang.String (default mapping).
There is a JAXB global customization that can help you achieve these tasks:

listitem.para: Eliminating JAXBElements as much as possible
Giving you a better, more typed binding in general
Using plural property names where applicable

section.para: Then simply run your wsimport and pass this binding customization file
See Kohsuke's blog for more details.

section.title: Generating Javadocs from WSDL documentation
section.para: wsimport can map the documentation inside the WSDL that can map as corresponding Javadoc on the generated classes. The documentation inside the WSDL should be done using standard WSDL 1.1 element: <wsdl:documentation>.

It is important to note that not everythign in the WSDL maps to Java class, the table below shows wsdl:documentation to Javadoc mapping for various WSDL compoenents that correspond to the generated Java class.

row.entry: As a Javadoc on the generated Service Endpoint Interface (SEI) class
As a Javadoc on the corresponding method of the generated SEI class
As a Javadoc on the generated Service class
As a Javadoc on the generated getXYZPort() methods of the Service class

section.para: Let us see a sample wsdl with documentation and the generated Java classes:

example.title: WSDL with documentation
example.programlisting:
<wsdl:portType name="HelloWorld"> <wsdl:documentation>This is a simple HelloWorld service. </wsdl:documentation> <wsdl:operation name="echo"> <wsdl:documentation>This operation simply echoes back whatever it receives </wsdl:documentation> <wsdl:input message="tns:echoRequest"/> <wsdl:output message="tns:echoResponse"/> </wsdl:operation> </wsdl:portType>
<service name="HelloService"> <wsdl:documentation>This is a simple HelloWorld service. </wsdl:documentation> <port name="HelloWorldPort" binding="tns:HelloWorldBinding"> <wsdl:documentation>A SOAP 1.1 port</wsdl:documentation> <soap:address location="http://localhost/HelloService"/> </port> </service>

section.para: In the above WSDL the documentation is mentioned using standard WSDL 1.1 element: <wsdl:documentation>. Running wsimport on this will generate Javadoc on the SEI and Service class.

section.title: Passing Java Compiler options to Wsimport
section.para: wsimport invokes Javac to compile the generated classes. There is no option currently to pass any options to the compiler. You can use -Xnocompile option of wsimport to not compile the generated classes. But, this would require you to compile the generated sources separately in your project.

note.para: This would be useful, if you are developing the Web service/Client on JDK 6 and you want to deploy it on JDK 5. Since there is no option to pass Javac tool option "-target 1.5" directly, you can use -Xnocompile option of wsimport and further compile it yourself.
